caption.title: Entrenchment in the population (of sequences carrying the mutation) for four major classes of resistance mutations in HIV-1 subtype B: A DRM is entrenched in the population if at least ~50% or more of the sequences containing the mutation entrench it (i.e Δ⁢E=Ew⁢i⁢l⁢d-E⁢m⁢u⁢t>0).
caption.p: We catalog entrenchment in the population (of sequences carrying the mutation) for all primary DRMs appearing at ~1% frequency or more, and our study reveals mutations in response to NNRTIs are much less entrenched in the population (of sequences carrying the mutation) than others.

caption.title: Table showing entrenchment in the population (of sequences carrying the mutation) for primary resistance mutations against NRTIs.
Table showing entrenchment in the population (of sequences carrying the mutation) for primary resistance mutations against NNRTIs.
Table showing entrenchment in the population (of sequences carrying the mutation) for primary resistance mutations against PIs.
Table showing entrenchment in the population (of sequences carrying the mutation) for primary resistance mutations against INSTIs.

tr.td: DRMs entrenched in the population (of sequences carrying the mutation)
Number of DRMs conferring high-level resistance
High-level resistance DRMs entrenched in the population (of sequences carrying the mutation)

fn.p: Source: Results shown in this table are based on calculations for ‘entrenchment in the population’ (of sequences carrying the mutation) for each primary DRM occurring at ~1% frequency or more in HIV-1 RT, PR, and IN, respectively as shown in Table 2—source data 1, Table 2—source data 2, Table 2—source data 3 and Table 2—source data 4. Resistance levels are determined according to Stanford HIVDB (Rhee et al., 2003; Shafer, 2006) mutation scores for PIs, NRTIs, NNRTIs, and INSTIs.
